I liked the fries. They had an interesting crisp to them. I like the buffalo sauce that came with them. Reminded me of Cholula hot sauce and apple sauce. My friends liked the ranch more.

The pizza wasn't as greasy as the slice I had before and very cheesy. The crust was more cracker-y than chewy. I like the Margherita a lot more than the veggie.  

Service was alright.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Don't come here for the pizza, it's nothing special. I had high hopes for their slices because it seemed like they did them on demand as opposed to reheating something that'd been sitting around for hours. The thin crust slice was too greasy and crunchy for my tastes.

It does seem like a nice neighborhood place. They have an L-shaped bar where you can order drinks and food. The crowd seemed quite friendly.
author: Rocky A.

description: Giant slice customized exactly how you like it! With grinders on the menu and a Celtics record pennant on the wall, this East Coast girl felt right at home, but also with a surfer vibe that reminded me that I was in the Sunset.
author: Jessica R.

description:
This place has damn good pizza.  The service is also friendly as hell, but I do have one issue with the place that's forced me down to 4 stars from 5 stars.

What the fuck is up with not serving grinders after 4.30pm?  I mean, who the fuck does that kinda shit?  Either you serve something, or you don't.  This isn't Gary Dankos--No seasonal or time based menu here sweetie.  

Think of us as fish.  You create this amazing bait, aka Grinders, which are fucking amazing by the way, to catch us in the day.  So we stumble down from our apartment, usually really fucking high and/or drunk, during the day to enjoy a few pitchers, some pie, and of course your grinders.  

Then nightfall creeps its way into the lower sunset, and we start hitting bong's and tall can's like it's goin out of style.  Suddenly, someone suggests a grinder.  Fucking great, I want 3, and "NO" none of you fat fuckers who call themselves my friends can't have any of mines, so get your own.  Sure enough, we make our way down there, and we ask for our grinders.  

"We don't serve them after 4.30p, it's on the menu.  Everyone misses that".....

Uhhhhhhhhhhmmmm......ooooooooookkkkkkaaaaaayyyyyyyyyyyyyy....... interesting business strategy.  "Everyone" misses that because they want their god damn grinders after 4.30pm.  

So we sit down for a beer and ask, 

"Why don't you sell grinders at night", as we settle for a slice.  Pssh...whatever.  I really wanted to ask, "What the fuck is your problem?  People love your shit, so give it to 'em!  Not only that, but they'll pay you for it!  Shit, raise the price if  you must!"  But I didn't......inside voice..inside voice....    

"We're just too busy and can't make them during the night".  

So being that I'm in the restaurant business I see that their pizza toppings cross utilize every product that the sandwiches use in the exception of the amoroso rolls (which are great!), meatballs, turkey, and condiments.  Every other ingredient is used on the pizza!  

So here's the deal, I suggest a bain-marie (spelling?) for the meatballs.  Surely you could squeeze the turkey and condiments into a cooler or an ice bath and of course a small shelf to house the bread.  Then again, I hate when people tell me how to run my business, and here I am doing the same thing.  I guess what I really want to say is: " Your grinders are fucking delicious and many of us probably won't frequent at night without those addicting little fuckers.  Your pie is great, don't get me wrong.  But those little grinders are a magical world for a bunch of high and drunken heathens or other fogheads who're just in the mood for something different than pizza in the LSD.     

Please stop fucking with your heads and stomachs and bring back your grinders at night!  The balance of the universe as well as the lower sunset district depends on this!

Don't leave us waiting.....
author: Willie W.

description: Pizza was much better than I expected.  Much more flavorful than your standard slice place.  Lots of toppings, and a nice crispy crust.  If you're looking for a nice greasy piece of pizza after a night out at the bars, this should be your destination of choice if you're in the area.
author: Joshua W.

description:
Whoa, are the rest of you smoking crack?  Just picked up a pie and some wings from TPPON and may i just say, what a glorious pile of shit I got for my $30.  I wanted to love this place, i really did.  Maybe it was an off night. 

 The pizza crust was good but the toppings were greeeezy, the sausage crumbly and mealy, the pepperoni was aiight (if you can taste it through the greezze).  The wings were nothing special, sauce was that shit that you can buy in a jug at costco (Tom's or Frank's or whoever's flammin hot wing sauce).  Both the ranch and bleu cheese dressings were a watery mess, GROSS! 

 Pizza Place, if you are reading this, please get it together, we really really want to like you.
author: Emily X.

description:
I LOVE this pizza!  I really aprreciate a true east coast pizza and The Pizza Place on Noriega has given me just that!  My search is finally over.  The sunset is lucky to have this gem in their backyard.  
My only wish is that the pizza were not so expensive.
author: K K.

description:
Five stars for ambience alone.  Yeah, it's loud, but the right kind of loud.  Family-style loud.  Funky awesome music loud.  Folks having a great time loud.  Awesome draft beer selection loud.  Locals only loud!

Food-wise, I really do love it.  I can not understand who is getting a soggy pizza...?  If anything, I might complain that the edges of the crust are too hard, but the bottom is always beautifully, evenly browned.  We usually get a coppacola pizza.

The "Timmy's," a vegan pizza that is actually worth eating, has pesto which sinks down into the crust, making it delightfully crispy in places.  The thinly-sliced potato makes up for the lack of cheese, by adding a nice chewy toothiness.  Thank you for having vegan options!  We love our vegans, and we love to eat with them!  I pretend it's for them that I order the roasted cauliflower with orange segments and chopped olives, but it's really for me.  'Cause it's GOOD!  And, I think I like the sweet potato fries even better than I like the wings!

LOVE the fresh salads.  Usually pizza-place salads are sucky -- often they are gross and downright slimy.  Not here!  The "wedge" is not very wedge-shaped, but does hit all the high points of the wedge salad concept.  Chunky iceberg and blue cheese dressing with super-thinly sliced radish, onion, shredded carrot and toasted walnuts.  The waitress asked if we wanted bacon on it last time, and I said no, in honor of my husband, but I really meant YES!  YES bacon!  However, the walnuts added the right note of toasty richness, so the bacon was not missed.

Recently, we have come to know the greatness of their sandwiches.  Served 12-4:30, they are VERY GOOD.  I get turkey-bacon-cheddar, husband gets the Italian.  They come with great fixins on fresh, good rolls.  I like the way the stuff is cut: the onions are super-wafer-thin and the pickles are chopped.  Makes for easy and happy eating.

The official home of Dog-walker Pizza Night, pretty much every Thursday around 7.  We're the ones talking about dog poop, even though we're eating.  Sorry about that.
author: Teal H.

description:
Once more unto the fog, dear friends.

Yes, for some inexplicable reason I found myself at the far end of Noriega two nights in a row.  (Well, actually it's pretty explicable, but I'll spare you.)  Now, one thing you take for granted coming out this way is that you can walk right in and sit right down.  But apparently those Sunset folks aren't kidding when they say that this is the only good pizza place out here, because it was packed (admittedly, it was a Friday).  It seems like they're still figuring out crowd control here, because there was no obvious sign about seating and they twice tried to seat us at spaces that turned out to be taken (cuz around here you can hold a table with a jacket or a beer).  All in all, it felt much more like the dinner rush at a ski village pizza-pub than San Francisco, but of course that's part of the charm.  In fact, it reminds me a lot of the Riptide scene -- definitely a worthy post-dinner stop if you're out this way.

But the important thing is, how's the pizza?  I'm happy to say that it's wicked good.  We tried the hawaiian, which is gourmet'd up with feta and coppacola ham.  It was piping hot and very dense, so a 14" is plenty to satiate 2 people.  Plus (and this is always a plus) a new type of beer!  Eel River Organic Amber Ale, from that magical happy land we call the North Coast.  And in spite of the wait (both for tables and food), the service is still nice and attentive, and you'll feel like a local even if you're from way back east (like, you know, twin peaks).

One thing though - why don't they have a sign?
author: Wes M.

description:
PIZZA
Can get nearly any pizza on the menu by the slice.  Slices are huge and just under $4 for a fatty good one.  It's thin crust, seems to be hand tossed, and is pretty dense.  A little too oily IMO, but the ingredients are top notch and the pizza is flavorful.  I probably wouldn't make any special trips to come here (Pizzeta is much better IMO, and only blocks away from my place).  Still, it's good and I'd eat here if I was in the hood.
author: Dan M.

description: Been coming here since it first opened. The food quality, customer service, and clientele was a lot different then. Now there aint nothing but a bunch of hipsters. Sorry hipsters, you are always too late on everything.
author: A W.

description:
We came in here on Valentine's Night with our family and I am sorry to say that this  will be the last time! I have wanted to love 'the pizza place' but I have never been so disappointed with service in a restaurant until now. Just check and see who you scheduled on this Valentine's Thursday and you will know what I am talking about! This experience has prompted me to write my first review on Yelp!! To say we were ignored and blown off would be an understatement. Every time we have walked in with our kids, we get a vibe like you don't want us there. Your waitresses are rude and inexperienced. I kept saying that maybe it was an 'off' night for them but how can it be 'off' every time? I like your pizza (even though it can be soggy and flimsy) but i'd rather eat a crappy pizza in a restaurant you feel welcomed in. We were born and raised in the sunset and you just lost customers that will tell others to BEWARE! If an owner is reading this...creating a family-friendly vibe in your pizza place and catering to the neighborhood would serve you well!! 
This could've been a gem in the sunset...you guys should be ashamed of yourselves!
author: Sunny D.

description:
I originally gave this place 3 stars bc their service was below par, pizzas were salty and greasy.  Just bc there are cheeses on the pizzas doesn't mean it have to be greasy.   

But since some one emailed me and criticized my review.   Probably from  establishment,  I hope not.  I'm down graded this place to one star.
author: Frank L.

description:
I just had my daughter's third birthday here, and I'm so glad I did. I can't tell you how close I was to booking the party at Chuck E Cheese. Brrr. (Big ups and thanks to the Yelpers with their scathing 1 star reviews who talked me out of it.) Instead, we had awesome pizza, kick-ass apps and pitchers of delicious beer. Beer! At a third birthday party! (Yes, I know CEC also offers beer, but I think they're required to by the Geneva Convention so as to offset the tortuous nature of their establishment .) 

 The staff was beyond amazing. They made it so simple. We just ordered pizzas by email and handed over a credit card after the party. And the kids loved it! We also had a balloon guy...so that added to the fun. We booked the party room, which has one big long table and is set off the main dining room, but not too far off. In fact, I was a bit nervous about our raucousness--but not one person in the main dining room complained about our loud, balloon-popping bunch. Ah. The power of pizza!
author: Melinda B.

description:
In addition to having a specifically-listed-as-vegan pizza called "Timmy's Pie" (FYI the specificity is not only conscientious but appreciated, especially when it comes to pizza places) The Pizza Place has vegan pesto. Now, Rainbow Grocery has vegan pesto. So do a few other grocery stores and specifically vegan restaurants. But a pizza place? It's often a crapshoot to get pesto anywhere since "traditional" recipes can call for anything from pinenuts to parmsean to no-garlic. They don't currently have vegan cheese offerings but you know what? I don't need to get vegan cheese everytime I get a pizza. I really don't - and I love the vegan pie the way they serve it up, with buttery-thin potatoes and other such goodness. 

The inside of The Pizza Place is big but not like a cafeteria, dark but not pretentious and has a car built into the wall. The people working there were chill, the people eating there were chill, and I was totally my own spazzy version of ''chill' after ingesting the majority of the delicious pizza I ordered.
author: M M.

description:
I am happy that there is good pizza just right across the park. 
It was busy but not packed for a Tuesday night. My dining companion and I enjoyed an iceberg salad  with radish, toasted walnuts, red onions, carrots,blue cheese dressing and parsley. Go ahead and splurge the $1 for warm bacon! Also if you like blue cheese dressing order extra on the side. 
We enjoyed an eel river amber ale and a medium Molinari salami pizza with caramelized onions. It was enough for two people with leftovers. The pizza was delicious. 
Service was friendly and attentive. It is a very casual atmosphere and very clean.
I am excited that there is good pizza near by.
Corkage is $12,
author: Jennifer S.

description:
We met some good friends and fellow yelpers here for dinner.

We drove by it and back again because there is actually no signage here. What a great place. What i really liked was the eclectic mix of people here. 

The four of us ordered the Dimitri. A Large is huge! With the four of us, we actually had 3 pieces of pizza left over.

It was great pizza with good service. 
One of the negatives was that the music that was playing, although great music, was just a bit too loud. It made it a bit tough to hear other people talking.

Not a big menu, but a good menu for a good, and not to pricey dinner or lunch.  The perfect ending of the meal was the root beer float! YUM
author: Christine S.

description:
Cool little pizza place. The pizza is pretty good and the kids that work there are friendly.

What more can you ask for.
author: Sara L.

description:
You know the kind of hangover that leaves you popping tylenol like candy & sleeping the entire day away, waking up only to chug another glass of water & pass back out? Now, what about the ravenous hunger that hits right when you finally roll out of bed, which is usually accompanied by intense groaning from the pit of your stomach that says "Thanks for all the alcohol last night, asshole. Way to feed me. Seriously, you can't even choke down piece of toast or a bagel or anything?"

Well, The Pizza Place on Noriega knows that type of hunger. Their mission statement actually details this explicitly (I bet it does, anyway). The only possible way this place could be improved upon is if they were magically able to get your pizza to you right when you walked in the door.

This is a seriously down-home pizza establishment. Delicious thin crust pizza that I believe could hold up if you stuck it across the street from Ray's (pick a Ray's, there are like 100 of 'em) in NYC.

I don't know how long this joint's been open, but I only recently heard about it for the frist time. I wish I lived closer so I could be a regular.
author: Pete J.

description: This is the only pizza place on the west coast that makes this transplanted east coaster happy.  I was also surprised at how great their "non-pizza" selections are. I have tried several different pizzas and appetizers and every single thing I have tried here has been absolutely delicious. You can tell they are using high quality ingredients. As has already been mentioned by other reviewers the sweet potato wedges, which are served with the best blue cheese dressing I have ever had, are not to be missed.  Service is always efficient and friendly. Thanks Pizza Place for saving me thousands of dollars on airfare :-)
author: Sandy M.

description: Live in the neighborhood so i decided to give it another shot unfortunately same old thing. The pizza is TOOOOOOO GREASY!
author: Michael W.

description: Great East Coast Style pie, grinders are very good, small but tasty assortment of beer and wine, lots of other tasty sides and salads.  Pizzas are big and worth every penny.  Be careful of too many veggies, they can make pie soggy.  When it's busy you can feel they're forgetting about you.  Could probably use a host/ hostess when it is busy.
author: Greg L.

description:
This is what a neighborhood pizza place is supposed to be: delicious pies, good beer selection, super friendly wait staff, and festive atmosphere.  I love the Margherita Pizza and the super yummy salads (they're all good).  Best yet, they'll do whatever you like to the get just the right pizza pie.  We had half fresh and half roasted garlic with on one just to see what we liked better. (Roasted for sure)

I have been here at least a dozen times since the summer and I haven't had a bad experience yet.  Each time there's the same great service and super yummy food.

Rumor has it they're expanding... so this will take care of the long wait for tables on weekends!
author: Micaela H.

description:
The pizza here is REALLY good. The Rotten Robby was my favorite. 

If you have a large group of people (8+), you might want to call in advance and see if they have seating. If all the group tables are taken, they aren't too flexible about combining tables together because they would like to cater to smaller parties too. But if you have a party of 2-6, this place is perfect. 

I am an impatient guy, and I think next time I have a pizza craving, I would just order in advance and get the pizza to go. The pizza takes about 40 minutes and I see a lot of people go this route and pick up their pizza instead.
author: nate c.

description:
So my birthday was a few days back. i got a big group of friends to come out to the beach to park chalet on a rainy night mid-holiday week. we had a drink, socialized, etc. but just as we all ordered food, POOF! the power went out. we waited. they put candles around. it was feeling romantic...but alas, we were HUNGRY and the kitchen had to close. apparently half of the Richmond district lost power that night too. 

think quick...what to do? 

The pizza place on Noriega awesomely saved my birthday dinner by accommodating 20+ hungry people right away without a reservation. The pizza was great (thin and crispy crust), and so were the yam fries (fat ones with yummy dipping sauce). the salad was good too (i had to pick around the bacon). worth a trip out there even if you're not a local.
author: Isabel C.

description:
We already know that the pizza here is best of class, but did you know that they now serve grinders as well?

It's true, and they even brought back the 'save a chicken', a fake chicken based sandwich from Dean's Deli which used to be in this location. The sandwiches are amazing, I really like the save a chicken with added bacon (ask them to save the chicken and kill the pig).

I also recommend the Italian and, if you're feeling brave, check out the buffalo style turkey sub, they use the same tangy spicy buffalo and blue cheese sauces as the fabulous wings, but on a sub.
author: Alf W.

description: Grreat east coasty pizza place, with a very e.c. Iceberg lettuce salad that actually rocks! My kinda place for the thin crust.
author: Joel W.

description:
i can honestly say that this is one of my favorite go to places in the city.  not only is it literally around the block from me, but the staff is super cool.  i've been here countless times and have never had a bad experience food wise or service wise.  their pizzas are crisp and yummy, and they have really good starter salads.  don't forget to try the sweet potato fries!  

i've had almost all of their specialty pies, and i would order them all again.  my personal favorites are the dmitri and the spicoli.  i don't know what it is, but i just can not resist double cheese and sausage.

while the food is scrumptious i also want to let the world know why else i love this restaurant...they are big on community!  if you go into their second room you will notice the little league pictures up on the wall.  on more than one occasion that room has been filled with hyper kids ready to get their grub on after a game.  also, they were part organizers for a block party on noriega @46th a couple of weeks ago.  this area isn't a big bustling community where you see people out with their strollers and dogs like it's noe valley, so i appreciate the sentiment.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Props to The PP on Noriega. I mean any form of life out in the "Set" is something special. The place has a pulse. Occupying a corner slice of Noriega, x-street from Toyose, The Pizza Place on Noriega serves up some fun 'Za & brew on tap with the friendliest staff in town aiming to please w/ out any BS. Wait staff is downright neighborly making everyone feel right at home.  

The Pizza is relatively good. I wouldn't say it's the BEST in the West, but it's some of the best East Coast styled pizza that you'll find near OB and SF in general. Surfers finally have a place to frequent other than Java Beach.

Passed by on a lark after a little chilli-O time on OB. Was starved and passed PPON by accident. The place was packed with surfers and students. They had just closed, but the waitress was friendly and kind. Turned out her boyfriend, who runs the place, had an some extra dough and was willing to bake another pie. They have some great brew on tap, and what's Pizza without brew? NOTHING! Certainly best Za in the Sunset and probably the Richmond too. The owners are from New England, and being a Boston boy myself,  I gotta spread the love. 

Worth the patronage if you're going to be nearby or just want to feel like your in a homey environment instead of a Pizza Hut.
author: Johnny C.

description: We LOVE this place, and we go all the time!!! The food is DELICIOUS and the staff is friendly. Very kid-friendly place, and if you live in the neighborhood, you're sure to see your friends and neighbors there when you go :) Highly recommended.
author: Beth W.

description: Have I mentioned how much I LOVE pizza??? I love it!!! We got the pizza margherita and while it's not so much like the traditional margherita (slabs of mozz  with tomatoes slices and basil leaves), it was still very good :) I am a big basil fan so I was glad they provided ample basil and the service was good. Prices not too bad, and serving size very good. My friends stuffed themselves to the outer limit whereas I chose to save my leftovers for later, as I'm prone to do as to extend the pleasurable experience to the day after. They wrapped up the leftovers nicely for us. Oh, but don't go here if you're on like a serious romantic date, cuz they got kids running around lol.
author: sigourney w.

description: Love, love the pizza. Great friendly staff and close by my house. We love the Demitri so good and tastey and got its name from Demetri who is owner of the produce store next block up... The place is always busy with families, girls night out, football /baseball fans and great relaxed feel to the place. We get a take out every other week or so. Love it and recommend to all. Enjoy!
author: Noreen M.

description:
A friend of a friend did the handiwork for this place.  It has an airy feel and an open kitchen.  Both add to the casual atmosphere. 
The one thing I would change is something that distracted me all night... the artwork and frames on the wall were placed far too high.  I *know* it's a random observation for a pizza place but I noticed it and it left me disconcerted.  All dinner long it was like we were waiting for a tribe of extremely tall people to enter and use the space as a gallery. 

The food, on the other hand, was pretty edible.  The pizza had a much more Italian flair than you normally find in SF.  Now, I like the American-style pizza selection in SF a lot... but every once in a while it's nice to have the fresher, lighter flavor of the kind of pizza that Noriega offers.  The chunk of iceberg lettuce salad was fun too.  I'm no huge fan of iceberg but it was a fun and whimsical change.

The crowd was fun but loud and the lighting, instead of feeling like "we're trying to set a mood here" felt somewhat like someone forgot to turn on all the lights.  I may, at some point, wander back to this place but I probably won't make it a priority.
author: Rashmi N.

description:
I have grown up just a half a block away from this corner and have known it since it was "Dean's Deli". My family and I would take our home daycare kids with us to get sandwiches for lunch and the hospitality there was amazing.

The first day of opening, my boyfriend and I went to the Pizza Place to try it out and our first impression was not a positive one, except for the fact that the staff seemed friendly. Later as it grew more popular, we came to have their chicken wings which were amazing, but better with ranch dressing (by the way). However, the price...well it's not as friendly to those of us with wallets of the same size. 

Later on, when my aunt treated us out to dinner there, I was not comfortable with the ambiance of the whole place. It was crowded, smelly, and very noisy, but at least the waiter was very friendly. Now to the Pizza. I have had the best pizza slices on 19th and Taraval, even though it's not a sit down eatery like the Pizza Place. The pizza is oily, very greasy but the Rotten Robbie and hawaiian style one is pretty good.. I definitely would not recommend anyone going to the Pizza Place if they want fabulous pizza.

However, one good thing about the place besides the staff is that they are (if they haven't already) expanding a little which might clear up the congestion and their salads are still very delicious. I prefer the spinach salad with cranberries and bacon bits, it's very savory.
author: Heather T.

description:
I want to like this place.

Cool surfer rocker dudes (prolly part-timing to get that beach party money), spacious, corner location, big windows, clean and cool looking kitchen.  And beer.

Ok, I speak only for the slices - I did not order an entire pie.  I did order a cheese and a few sausage mushroom.  But the cheese was pretty much laying in it's own oil.  It kinda looked like a wet Freddy Krueger's face.  The edge crust was decent - thin but a bit slimy.  

The sausage mushroom was pretty crazy not cool.  The mushrooms were over done and then they slap on some furry dried scallop looking jerky sausage cotton that tasted like salty saw dust.   What is going on here?  I took it to go, so when I opened it up, it looked like a sausage and red carpet pizza.  Weird.  But maybe bad batch?

The place was pretty crowded with what looked like returning patrons, so  I probably got a bammer batch.  I probably would check it out again if I'm in the area since the place is pretty clean and large.
author: Isaac L.

description: Very decent pizzas and the place is cool. A little bit too expensive even if the pizzas are really big.
author: Dominique B.

description: whoever thought of jalapenos on pizza is a genius!!!!! the Rotten Robby is amazing! with crust so thin and jalapenos slightly toasted it's my ultimate comfort food! although... it is on the greasy side..but then again, i don't believe in comfort food without the dirty grease
author: Jen C.

description:
This is one of those places that is trying to make the sunset cool and hip.
Don't do it. I like the sunset:  quiet, foggy and understated.
Too late, the word is out, this place is packed.

Good thin crust pizza Boston style, 
Good appetizers Cali style: olives, cauliflower and sweet potato fries.

Not the fastest service.
author: forrest l.

description:
PRO:  Nice atmosphere.  Friendly staff.  Cool music blasting. Got Pabst Blue Ribbon on tap.  Tasty thin crust pizza!

CON:  The decorations are hung too high.  Pepperoni and sausage pizzas are overly greasy.  On the pricey side for outer sunset.

CONCLUSION:  Nice option, especially since its a few blocks away.  A welcome addition to our hood.

TIP:  Order slices if its a party of 1-2, the pie if its more than 2.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
I have some issues with pizza in San Francisco.

1) As a native east coaster, I may just be a bit of a pizza snob.  I found some pizza here that's pretty good, decent, or tastes great but that's only because it's 2am and I've been drinking heavily, in which ALL pizza tastes good.  

2) Pizza and beer joints are hard to come by.  Sure, there are places that you can get some weird fancy pizza and a nice pint.. but I'm talking about a REAL pizza joint.. sit down with a bunch of buds, order a pitcher and a hot pie.. relaxed atmosphere and good tunes are also a plus!

Enter.. Pizza Place on Noriega!

I really like this place.  Ok, the pizza isn't the best I've ever had in my life.. but it's pretty darn good.  There's a decent beer selection too.. and if you're on a budget, the PRB pitchers are pretty cheap.

The location is great too!  The sunset is in need of more action, in my opinion.  I certainly don't loathe the neighborhood in the way that some do.. (after all, it's the BEACH), but I certainly think that the neighborhood has some fun spots, as well as lots of potential.  Pizza Place on Noriega is a perfect fit.

Even if you don't live in the Sunset, you should take a trip to the beach and hit up Pizza Place for some beers and pizza on your way out.. trust me, you'll likey!

Side note:  Apparently they were petitioning to stay open until 2am, and it's passed.  Not sure when that will take effect, but should be soon... yay!!
author: Chrissy S.

description:
Ordered take out, thus the limited 3 Star review. Had it been dine-in maybe we'd be talking about 4 Star pizzeria, but....

The Pizza Place makes a big ass pizza!!! I ordered a large thinking it was enough to suit my girl and I with the hopes of having a few slices leftover for the midnight munchies, but it turned out we had more than enough to send hose poor kids on American Idol a sample. Turned out though we didn't need to pay for shipping as the pizza wasn't too much to our liking and didn't want to make children on the brink of collapse suffer anymore. I'll give "The Pizza Place" "The Benefit of the Doubt" though as maybe the pie just wasn't our style. The pineapple and sausage pizza was less about the toppings than it was about the cheese and the sauce, maybe because of the size, making it hard to enjoy the flavor combos we were looking for. I know some places concentrate solely on toppings to hide subpar crusts, but hey, I ordered topping because I like them!

Along with this monster circle we had an order of sweet potato fries and a mixed greens salad. The fries were good as they weren't skinny like others places' and were paired with hot sauce and bleu cheese dressing making for an interesting flavor trifecta. They were also made fresh while I was waiting for the order to be completed which was a nice touch. The salad was a salad. Not too much to report there. 

The Pizza Place probably deserves more stars, but again it might just be one of those places you have to dine in. Take-out left me concentrating really hard on the food on my plate and less on the atmosphere that The Pizza Place seemed to have.... as I perceived in the seconds I was there anymore. Maybe I'll have to give it one more chance?
author: Marcos M.

description:
As a SF native who has always been wary of living in the Sunset, I am sooo glad I live here now and The Pizza Place is a major contributing factor to my change of heart.  The atmosphere is welcoming and casual in that beach lover/ surfer way.  The large windows make the place really bright even on our often foggy days.  I went on a Saturday afternoon and the place was filled with families which warmed my heart ... I'd call it family friendly.  I imagine it's also a cool place to hang out in the evening with a slightly different crowd.  

The service was friendly and efficient.  Not a lot of chit chat but I think that will come with more visits.  The music playing was Elvis Costello ...not too loud and very cool for a Saturday afternoon.  

Finally .. the food..  Yum yum!  In old style pizza tradition, we ordered the iceberg salad for 1 -2 people.  Definitely enough for 2.  Crispy fresh lettuce, delicious blue cheese dressing and we had the bacon sprinkled on top which was perfectly crispy and divine.  

I couldn't go without ordering the sweet potato fries and I'm glad we did.  The sauces are awesome, one super spicy deliciousness and the other a cool creamy pot of heaven.  The fries themselves are soft and velvety when you bite into them.  I immediately thought this is my new comfort food.  We paced ourselves with the fries and just ate one fry each ... maybe two fries : )  

We ordered the Rotten Robby: sausage, mushrooms, pesto, jalapeño, tomato sauce & cheese. I loved that it arrived a few minutes after we were done with our salad.  It was delicious.  The sauce is delicate and super fresh tasting.  I'm not a sausage fan at all but I will say I was pleased with this sausage.  It wasn't on the pie in big chunks which freaks me out.  It was small crumbles sprinkled liberally but balanced well with the other toppings so no one topping over powered the other.  

So ... run don't walk!  Even you mission hipsters who venture out to ocean beach in your one pair of shorts on a hot day, take a field trip to the Sunset and you'll be surprised to find some cool places and very cool people.
author: Wanda P.

description:
This place has managed to re-produce the pizza I ate growing up just outside of Boston, so I think it's great. They even have "grinders" (that's Boston talk for Sub sandwich). 

Great atmosphere and friendly staff make this a comfortable place when you want a great slice of pizza.
author: Jonathan W.

description: Wow, what a find!  The pizza was good, but we were even happier with the vibe.  Friendly service from people who seem like they enjoy their work, customers who clearly feel at home, kids, old folks, everybody's there.  And the iceberg lettuce with fresh bacon topping and blue cheese dressing, well, that was a good thing.  OK, they got the topping wrong on one of the slices, so this should be four stars, but these are really good folks and I'm giving them a five.
author: Natalia B.

description: Stood at the door for 10 minutes. No one said hello to seat us. All the staff avoided eye contact. LAME!
author: Chris C.

description:
When they first opened, I tried their pizza and disliked it very much. (i was told it was because I got cheese only) 

Recently tried it again, and the pizza was actually pretty decent. Not the best pizza ive ever had but it was definitely good.

Beer (and wine) on tap. 3$/pint 10$ for a pitcher of pabst 5$/pint 16$ for the good stuff. 

Its a cool place to hang out, close to the house. Friendly enviornment with a good lively ambiance, diverse crowd, young and old, hipsters and conservatists.
author: Boris S.

description: After church down the street, I was looking for a lunch spot and saw this on Yelp.  From the reviews, we had to try the buffalo wings.  They were good, but nothing too outstanding.  Not the best I ever had, but good.  The pizza was better.  Good thin crust, and tasty toppings. No one in our group had anything negative to say, and all ate with conviction.  The ambience was casual and service was attentive.  We would come back to try the grinders or other pizzas.
author: Michael N.

description: I was disappointed with their pizza. It was runny with sauce soaked into the crust making it soggy to eat.  The cheese was rubbery. Meats were sparse.  We waited a good half hour for the pizza which I would not have minded if it were good.  We wanted to try a local sunset place for a good decent pizza and this is definitely not my place.
author: Rose O.

description:
I love this place, I haven't been in awhile but when ever i crave a NY style  piece of pizza I always think of this place first, considering that I'm a new englander and so are the owners.  U can see all the Celtic's stuff everywhere.  

The chicken wings and side salads are a huge plus so don't forget those, what am I talking about?  Don't forget the pitchers of beer either and if you are low on cash they also have pbr by the pitcher, another huge plus in my book.  

Everyone who works here treats you like a human being and not just another customer,  they all have their own distinctive personality and i think it really helps with the overall atmosphere of the place.
author: Diana D.

description: Definitely one of the best pizzas I've ever had if not the best. Great salads and pork chile verde as well! Service was so and so, and wait for a pizza was quite long during the weekends but all worth it for the food. Had the Dimitri and it was absolutely delicious. Crispy crust with a really good flavor and the toppings on the pizza were very high quality.
author: Kevin H.

description: Loved it here, good pizza, great service and very child friendly! The slices are huge, east coast style, thin with great toppings.
author: Bob S.

description:
Timmy's Pie- only with Cheese (lots of it too) = heaven on earth. 'Nuff said.

Plus you definitely get what you pay for- pies are enormous and loaded with toppings. I'm from the East Coast and also from a pizza-making family- this place is the real deal and most definitely worth the drive out the Sunset (also a great post- beach day stop!)
author: Cole P.

description:
The vegetables they use are great. Pizza crust and cheese not so much. Place seems to have a good crowd some evenings enjoying the beer at the giant bar they have. Not much atmosphere inside the cavernous rooms. Bit like a dorm cafeteria with a few beer signs up on the wall.

Tried a couple different pizza's here and both times the crust was pretty burnt, the wait time long, and the toppings very scarce. I would recommend Brother's or Pasquale's for pizza anyday over this.

It does look like a good place to drink a few beers with some friends. I'd just probably eat somewhere else first. After enough beer its not going to matter anyway.
author: Peter S.

description:
Rotten Robby.  Yum! 
Besto.  Yum Yum!!
Sweet Potato Steak Fries.  Yum Yum Yum!!!
This is my new favorite local hangout, and by local I mean that I am willing to drive clear across town to get there.  The menu is both vegan and baconitarian friendly.  The staff is all uber-amiable, the food is outstanding plus its all affordable.  Its all too easy to stuff myself on an app and a slice and then just stick around for a few hours nursing a beer or 3 and chatting with whomever I might find myself seated near.  I anticipate making the trek from Russian Hill regularly.
author: Sky W.

description:
Flavorful, imaginative pizzas. I've tried 3 or 4 and loved every one of them. Order a big one and take the rest home. (Oh, btw, for connoisseurs: I don't judge pizza on how Italian or authentic it is.) I recommend the Sunset Aloha and the wilted baby spinach salad.

Noisy, often full of kids, but I don't care. People are friendly. Employees work their asses off. I think they put a 10-yr-old boy in charge of decor.
author: James B.

description:
Yummy pizza! Their style of pizza reminds me of pizza back in Jersey. Thin crust and greasy. Just perfect! Be sure to ask "BY THE SLICE." You can even add toppings to your big slice. 

Try their hot wings, too! They're crispy and pretty hot but just a little salty. WARNING: Do not dip wings into the blue cheese dressing. I repeat, do not dip wings into the blue cheese dressing if you know what's good for you.
author: Evanne G.

description:
I have only tried this place once. The Greek Pizza was good. Crispy crust, good flavor, not oily. BUT last night we tried to call in an order and the phone was busy for hours. Off the hook? That busy? 

I will try it again, perhaps this was a one time thing, but I need my Pizza place to be reliable.

**update 2/28/08 Yes its pretty much crowded all of the time. That means its good. I wish they delivered. Lazy me at 6 blocks away.
author: Amanda L.

description: Great addition to the sunset! I love the pizza place and go there pretty often. They are so different from any other pizza place I've ever been to. I love the neighborhood vibe, and they now have gluten free pizza!
author: Lisa M.

description: Walked in, sat down, waited 15 minutes & walked out. They clearly do not know anything about customer service! The people that worked there just stared at us and did not say one word. After being ignored for about 15 minutes we just walked out. I would give negative stars if I could.
author: Cyndi C.

description:
God bless these people.  Not only is it the only pizzeria off the ocean, but it's also damn good and great value.  We had a large half, Dimitiri (pepperoni, sausage, garlic and mushrooms) and half Besto (pesto topped with feta, potatoes and bell peppers).  The crust was great, the Dimitiri rocked, the garlic gave the tomato sauce a great kick and left my tongue in Flavor Country.  Besto was a zesty vegetarian option and the bell peppers were a great addition.  

The beer selection is good enough and for $12.50=pitcher of PBR or $16.50=pitcher of a variety of microbrews.  The wine list was sparse, but who needs wine with pizza, if you do, you're in the wrong neighborhood, go back to the Heights.  However, corkage is $12, a little high, but again who needs wine with pizza.

We also had the wings, saucy and decent but wouldn't order then again, I like mine more fried but the mixed green salad was great using fresh organic goods from the produce market up the street.

Long live this establishment .
author: A and K W.

description:
It cracks me up how many San Franciscans think the outer Sunset is so far from the rest of the city. When I hear this, I remind them that the city is only seven square miles. How far can anything really be? Maybe it's the time I lived in SoCal where a 20 minute drive was considered around the block which makes a quick drive out to the beach seem like nothing. 

Recently a few co-workers ventured out to the depths of the outer Sunset to visit The Pizza Place on Noriega. My co-worker's boyfriend works there and she had been raving about the surf hangout/pizza joint for a while. Our group instantly shrank once outer and Sunset were mentioned. However, I was one of the brave few who didn't give it a second thought. I'll travel to the end of the earth for good pizza. 

The place almost doesn't fit into the stereotypical Asian theme of the outer Sunset. The brightly lit pizza place sits on a corner and was bustling with lots of families, couples on dates and large groups of people throwing back pitchers of PBR. 

Our group ordered a variety of starters that included an amazing wilted spinach salad that was chock full of dried cranberries, feta and almonds, sweet potato steak fries that were delicately fried and a roasted cauliflower dish that had a spicy bite to it. 

We were warned that the large sized pizza would feed most of us in our group, but we decided to ignore the warning and went with a large Meat Head (every type of meat imaginable) and Veggie. 

The flavor combinations of the Spicoli, Rotten Robby and Besto all sounded good too, but alas, those had to wait for another visit. 

The prices are very reasonable. The large pizza, which is larger than any other large I've seen, runs between $21 and $25. 

If you're a San Franciscan who thinks the Sunset is like going to outer Siberia; trust me, The Pizza Place on Noriega is worth the trip.
author: Lee H.

description:
As a New Yorker, I have long considered all San Francisco pizza as largely uninteresting, tasteless or unnecessarily dressed up with awfully silly ingredients. And, please, don't get me started on the unfortunate and puzzling use of corn meal. 

The thin crust pizza here is really very, very good and reminds me of home. It's worth the trip.
author: Iana S.

description:
The large pizza is darn big, but the pizza isn't all that great. The crust is tasteless and the bottom is soggy. The toppings don't taste fresh at all. I got the veggie pizza.

The next time I got the margarita pizza and it was waaaay better. The crust was actually crisp on the bottom and not soggy. I'd recommend limiting the amount of toppings to avoid soggy crust.

I was excited to try the sweet potato fries and was pretty disappointed with what I got. They were mediocre at best - I'd pass next time. The blue cheese is super watery but the buffalo sauce was pretty good and tasty. 

This place is super chill and the staff is friendly - I wish the food was a bit better since it is so darn close to home.
author: Chili B.

description:
did i write a review about this place yet?

They have a car on the wall that has pizzas as wheels!! 4stars already for that!!

this place has a very Haight Street feel.....you know, kinda owned by hippy hipsters, cool people covered in tattoos and piercings that sell healthy pizzas.

Pretty good, you order at the counter and they bring it to you, personally i liked their salads more than the pizza, the pizza is kinda too healthy for me, we got the veggie one, no meat, either that or ALL meat, i didnt want to be constipated..so we went with the veggies.  BUT pizza IS supposed to be junk foody, it just didnt have the right feel. 

Im writing this as i am watching the olympix, i hope i didnt type anything wrong.  WOW , no typos!
author: kim w.

description: Love having this place in the neighborhood.  Good pizza (loving the Rotten Robby) and friendly folks.  My favorite thing to do is call ahead, wait a few and then walk down for a beer before my pizza is ready to schlep home.  Definitely worth trying out.  And a warning, the large is huge...
author: James S.

description:
I usually get pizza delivered because I hate pizzeria decor/filth. A friend of mine recommended this place to my boyfriend and I, and I think the words "brand new" struck a chord with me. This meant fresh paint and clean appliances. Yum. The bathroom was clean, the walls relatively free of greasy hand prints, but oi vey do they need to upgrade the "art".

They don't deliver, they had a nice amount of toppings, but the menu is limited. These peeza-pies are wicked greasy, and I'm not usually someone who takes a napkin and smashes it on  a slice -- but I felt it actually necessary. I had some pretty terrible heartburn for the rest of the day. It was tasty, but -- I think I'll stick with Brother's on Taravel. (They deliver, mainly.)
author: Serene L.

description:
LOVE...
Especially the beer and the vegan pizza. Their pizzas are thin crusted, perfect crunchy-chewy. The toppings are top-notch and delicious.  I haven't been disappointed with anything I've ordered. They also have good salads and appetizer's like sweet potato fries and an excellent olive medley which I love to eat with my pizza.  The sweet potato fries are not greasy at all but the vegan and besto pizzas can be heavy on the olive oil depending on who is making it.  So just ask to take it easy on the oil, if you care.
The place can be packed sometimes. The service is friendly and efficient and surfers for sure. Great neighborhood spot. When I've had a stressful day I immediately think of The Pizza Place for a beer and a slice.
author: Jessica D.

description: Huge slices, huge pizza! Really greasy though so make sure you have a roll of paper towels to sop up that grease!
author: Derrick L.

description:
I hate to give this place a poor rating because I really want to like the pizza. I enjoy the atmosphere and the menu seems so promising! I've been here 3 times and now I'm ready to write a review. 

The sweet potato fries and salads are good. I also had a few of their pomegranate/sparkling wine cocktails and they were tasty for this non-beer drinker (nice selection of that, too). 

The pizza is just terribly greasy and the crust is dry. The selection of toppings is unique but quickly add up to make an expensive pie. I felt obligated to eat the leftovers because I paid so damn much for it! Sadly it tasted even worse the next day. Despite putting it under the broiler in a sad attempt to revitalize it, it came out even greasier and was an inedible cheesy blob of grease. Sorry guys, no thanks.
author: Louis C.

description:
Good quality pizza - just be prepared to wait because it takes time to craft your pie. Or order in advance. 

I hear the meatball is good, will try that next time.
author: Eddie G.

description:
Sunset people don't mind the chill in the air, don't mind a little less of the sunshine, and don't mind driving a little further for "the city".  We have the beach, never have to hunt for parking, and can come home, face the water and jump off the merry-go-round for a little while.

That being said, Sunset people don't like to leave the Sunset once we get home to the Sunset - but the instinct to eat good pizza is one that will draw us out of our little salty corner...good news!!!  Good pizza FINALLY exists in the Sunset!!  Thank all that is good in this world for bringing us The Pizza Place!!  Crispy flat pizza that keeps its shape even loaded with toppings...toppings are all fresh and great quality (I suspect they are in cahoots with that awesome produce store up the street)...yummy yummy beers on draft, and they even have a decent wine selection if you aren't in the mood for beer with your pizza.  I loooooved the iceberg salad - something about fresh crispy crunchy nutrition-free lettuce that gets me everytime.

And the cherry on top is the staff is super friendly.  It truly is a home-base pizza shop that saves me the trip into town.  Thanks guys - soon we'll never have to leave the Sunset.
author: niselynne X.

description:
The pizza here is good and the salad is pretty good too. The employees are nice. What makes it really great is that it's near the beach.

Better than cheap chain pizza and simpler than fancy "gourmet' pizzas. It's regular pizza with good ingredients with no gimmicks. They also have a nice selection of beers.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Wait a minute.  Alright pizza, cold service and warm beer.  A block from the beach?  

No, no, you heard me wrong.  I said: AWESOME pizza, WARM service and COLD beer.  This place has an excellent antipasti plate (cherry peppers...hmmmm), light and crispy pie crust, creative toppings and a light and airy atmosphere.  I was dying to try the iceberg salad, but it'll have to wait until next time.  

Great open kitchen allows you to look at all the action.  Found a parking spot right out front, and could see the waves crashing on Ocean Beach from just a block away.  Oh, and there's a cutout of a 1980's Oldsmobile on the wall with spinning pizza wheels...

I've never seen a happier, more relaxed group of new restaurateurs...maybe its all the time they spend in the ocean.  Maybe its because they use organic ingredients and recycle their fryer oil.  Maybe they know that they're making the best pizza in town...

Look out Pizzeria Delfina...
author: Michael B.

description: I went here on a Sunday since my usual place of Pasquales on Sloat was closed (freaking cooks must have partied too much the night before). The large pizza here would be considered an X-lrg from other pizzerias. The slices are fat like NY slices where you have to fold it to eat. The crust is thin like NY. Sauce was ok and the toppings were not all that. Wasn't a fan of the sausage. It's more like ground sausage. If they were like NY Pizza they should cut the sausage into slices. If that were the case this place would be a 5 star. Pretty cool though cause they have the surf vibe and the \nnn/ for their logo. 8-D
author: Keoni U.

description: Another one of my favorite names.   It is a nice open place with a good bar and a fair amount of tables.  The slices are generously sized, $3 for a slice of cheese.  Nice place to sit and have a beer and eat pizza.
author: Jeff J.

description:
That Pizza Place on Noriega was mentioned in 7x7's article " Is the Outer Sunset the new Mission?"  I can't say that I agree with the article, but it did pique our interest to give the pizza place a try.

The space is huge.  Cleaner and newer than Naan N' Curry but for some reason, reminded me of it.  Maybe it's the giant space and the two sectioned-off rooms, and the comfort factor both shares.  Everyone looks really low key, like the place to go after you and your best bud from high school had a nice chatty reunion on your couch over a few beers, and now, your belly is growling but you are too lazy to go to a formal restaurant to continue your catching-up.  

Actually, I take that back.  You cannot go there when your stomach is growling.  On the menu it tells you it takes about 20-25 minutes to make the pizza, so unless you have some sweet potato fries (should've ordered that!) to munch on, you will seriously be staring at the giant car on the wall with the pizza wheels spinning over and over again like a couple of clocks going nowhere. 

My husband and I shared a medium Sunset Aloha. It's got feta, copparella, pineapples.  Pizza came in 8 slices, thin crust, and the flavor is pretty strong.  If the coppa didn't give it a kick to balance out the flavors, the whole thing would have been a bit too salty.  

It was a little too greasy for my taste, but my husband liked it.  And apparently I was the only one who could smell that kitchen grease on myself even after I got home.
author: Candice B.

description:
This place is unreal. I've been living out here for about 4 months and never discovered it until my friend came by with some magical flowers. We smoked some of the flowers and then went to pick up our half/half pizza. It almost felt like a dream. The whole time I was thinking my friend must have slipped some fairy dust into those flowers we smoked. 

When I was lit, it was awesome. When I was sober, it was awesome.
author: Wil M.

description:
What kind of name is The Pizza Place on Noriega? I drove all the way up and down Noriega street just to find this place and finally found it on the 3rd pass... 

Ok, not really, I walked there from my friends house a few blocks away who raved about this place. We stumbled back after a few to many PBR's from the tap.

This place is great, I live in the NOPA area and drive out here just for pizza on more than one occasion. The people who own it and work there are all cool, the customers are chill and you get to see the ocean and beach while your out there. You can even get a pizza and walk to the beach to eat it!

The best thing on the menu isn't really on the menu but just ask for it. The Dimitri (on the menu) ask for jalapenos and hot sauce on the side, they have tapatio in the back which goes on this pizza great. I also suggest you order a medium over a large as for some reason they seem to turn out a bit better. 

If they could only expand and get a back patio I would give this place a 5 stars.
author: Bobby B.

description:
ask anyone that knows me, and they will say i am not a fan of pizza. its the combination of heavy tomato sauce + grease + cheese that gets me. bleh!

HOWEVER... I COULD EAT HERE EVERYDAY!! 

they have a great selection of specialty pizzas, salads, apps, meatball dishes, and grinders. we started with a small salad and the vegan pizza. OMG it is SOOOO tasttyyyy. its made with vegan pesto and is absolutely delicious! mmmm!! thin crust, not too heavy... 

we came another time and tried the veggie pizza. the ingredients were SO fresh. the sauce was really good, not too heavy or tomato-pastey.. tasted like real tomatoes and olive oil. 

can't wait to come back. i definitely want to try the rotten robby, which i heard is amazing. and also the braised pork dinner. ohh i am so hungry!
author: Bobbie L.

description: I do take-outs at this place. The pizza's cool, they did upgraded the ambiance a bit, though I'm rating this place for the pizza and sauce and not the place itself. For the price it's decent, nothing gourmet but the awesomeness is what's it all about. As always a definite recommend when within the area or having a chow near the beach :)
author: Pierre B.

description:
Good neighborhood New York Style pizza. When buying by the slice, they are quick and hot. 

I love thin crust, I love TPPN.
author: Winnie L.

description:
Well, I've never posted on this before but felt motivated to write my first review based on my experiences here at the PPON.  I'm definitely no pizza connoisseur but I've had my fair share of pizza at various locations throughout the world and even in this city...

First, the things I liked:  This place was clean, a big improvement from the previous business.  They also had beer and wings, both of which go quite nice with a pizza.  And for those who need their salad fix, they had a few salads that looked pretty good.

Then, the things I didn't like:  The fact that no one really knew where my food was.  I ordered the dimitiri pizza and wings at the bar and waited for like 45 minutes to finally get my order.  In between that time, a few folks managed to pick up their orders and leave without any hassles.  I even saw one pizza made and put on top of the oven.  After 40 minutes, I asked for my wings and was given those.  Another 5 minutes later, someone finally realized that the pizza on top of the oven was mine.  Needless to say, by the time I got home (just down the road) my pizza and wings were cold.  Therefore I'm not sure whether I had a typical PPON meal.

As for the food, I'll try my best to rate the cold food.  The wings were friend and then served with hot sauce and blue cheese on the side.  I liked the crunchy hot wings but I feel that they would have been better if the wings were mixed with the sauce rather than put on the side.  They were definitely generous with the sauce and blue cheese, though.  However, the pizza was so-so.  The crust on this pizza was soggy (perhaps it's because my pizza was sitting there for about 1/2 hour).  Also, this pizza was a bit salty but I don't know whether that's from the meats or something else. 

Overall I'd rate this food average (mostly it's the wings that are the saving grace) but the customer service sucked.  There are better places in town to get pizza.
author: Marc W.

description:
The ambiance here is great!  I love that you can order a slice of pizza and pint of beer, chat with your neighbor or flip through one of the magazines they keep on hand.  The pizza is good (not OMG good, but it hits the spot when you are in the mood for pizza) and the spinach salad is delicious!!  It is pretty low profile, so keep that in mind when you go.
4/22/08 - update - had the meatball sandwich here for lunch.  It was OMG good!!!! Holy Cow!!!!  The fiance had the Italian Sub - that was awesome too!  Then we had the root beer float.  SWEET MOTHER OF JESUS!!! Our toes curled, then we cuddled.
author: Curtis H.

description: We tried this place about 4 years ago and thought is was just O.K., so decided to give it a second shot.  Still just O.K.  I suppose its good if you live in the area since there isn't a lot of competition, its convenient and there is a decent selection of beers on tap, but the pizza is nothing to write home about, crust is bland and nothing special about the toppings or combinations.  If I'm in the mood for a regular pie (e.g. not Gialina, Pizzeria Delfina, Flour + Water, etc.) then I actually prefer a sausage and onion pizza from Pasquales on Sloat, cheaper and slightly better quality ingredients.
author: kenneth h.

description: The boy and I came in on a lazy Tuesday afternoon and were the only customers there. Service was mediocre and a bit slow considering we were the only table needing service. We ordered sweet potato steak fries and dmitri pizza. Both were tasty and we had plenty of leftovers to take home. The leftover pizza was also really good the next day, although it was pretty greasy when reheated. But who cares when its that good? I'm looking forward to returning and trying other things on their expansive menu.
author: Eme L.

description:
This place is TERRIBLE!!!  Do NOT come here if you are planning on having a wonderful night.  We arrived and it was a busy.  We expected a wait for our food but not this long!  We got there at 6:45 ordered a pitcher and a 14" pizza when we sat down to STICKY TABLES.  at 8:05 we asked our server if our pizza was close and she started to give us attitude about how they were really busy and that if were "nicer" we would have gotten a free pitcher.  She said, "It takes 35 minutes to make a pizza and when we're busy it takes longer."  I saw 20+ pizzas go out before we left!  I asked for the manager and she said "There IS NO MANAGER!" ON A SATURDAY NIGHT!?  So we paid for the beer and left.

Let me just say, the party of 6 that got there 10 minutes after us got their 20" pizza when we left!  WTF?
author: Zak F.

description:
well, I am not a native new yorker but i know a good pizza when I see one.
Wow, really disappointed!!!  My mother in law says the pizza at costco is better, i completely agree.  the wings are pretty good though, nice and crispy with a very vinegar-y sauce, the way i like em.
but geez, the pizza was just so disapointing.  too bad, i could have used a place really close for emergency dinners/lunches for the kids.
Guess i'll stick with seniore's and brother's.
author: Rio K.

description:
I went the whole gamut for lunch: 3 slices of different pizzas and the sweet potato steak fries...I can't finish it of course, so lunch will be fun for the next few days...

For some reason I kept missing the place for the past 2 days...maybe cause there wasn't a freakin sign out in front or that you just can't tell if it is a restaurant...but today I scored!

By far of the three selections I sampled: I loved the Besto: Pesto sauce, potato slices with feta. The combination of savory and the potatos were just right. I didn't like the fact that it was so greasy it melted through the paper bags, but I've had grease before.

The Aloha was "eh" I don't like the feta on it. It detracted from the overall flavors of the ham and pineapple. The Veggie was all right as well...it just kept dying from overkill of vegetables...my poor crust was a sopping mess.

The Sweet potatoes were nicely seasoned and thick too. I don't like the spicy bbq sauce cause the oils rose to the top like bad vinaigrette. I rather use hot chili sweet Thai sauce to dip instead...god that's good. 

Overall the place is clean and tons of beach cruiser dudes. (Hey, I need eye candy too). But anyplace that serves Anchor Steam is always a must.

Be warned by the slice prices aren't listed so don't be shocked to see some slices like the Besto and the Veggie be $4 and the Aloha was $3.50.

Parking is plentiful...and free. Service was brisk and cheerful. Q_Q...
author: Pauline L.

description:
last night was delish.

we had the wings & fries & mixed green salad. fabulous!

you guys might want to adjust the oven temp because of the weather....pizza this time around although was tasty...was a little on the soggy side :(

still love ya...will be back.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
So, we were expecting a really good night - our friends had raved about this place - kid friendly, good food, outdoor patio etc. etc.
Eek! Not the place for this kind of experience at all - the food was marginal, but definitly not worth $60 for a medium pizza (kinda greasy) a half carafe of wine (0verpriced), some collard greens and a warm spinach salad (definitely the best part of the meal) . Then, to top it off, while waiting (for some time) for our check, the skinny tattoed pizza oven guy proceeded to request we keep our children under control. 
We are definitley unimpressed and not interested in eating here again!  Good luck Pizza Place on Noriega!
author: Trish B.

description:
I love that there's a cool hangout pizza joint in my neighborhood. I really wish the food was better, though. This place is pretty no-frills, and the service can be either ambivalent or really friendly, seems to change every time I go in. It's never bad service- sometimes you can tell your server just doesn't care overly much, doesn't check in, etc. But it's not fine dining, so it's not really a problem that they're not hanging over your shoulder the whole time- and sometimes you get a really friendly person. 

The food isn't great though. They make their own ranch and blue cheese dressings, which are both really odd tasting and watery. Blue cheese should be thick and creamy and I have no idea what's going on with theirs, and I normally like ranch but can't handle the flavor of theirs. The pizza isn't great either, and a bit overpriced. They do, however, offer a gluten free pizza, which I hope is awesome since I can't eat wheat all of a sudden. I have yet to try it, but I'll be back sometime so I can see if it's any good.
author: Brandi C.

description:
This place is great! Friendly staff, casual vibe. You have the surfers at the bar, young adults as well as families in the dining area. Great hangover food. Or a place to start off your night of debauchery. 

If it's really busy it might take a while to get your pie, but that gives you more time to drink, so we're even! I recommend the Rotten Robbie with a pitcher of Trumer...
author: J D.

description:
The hawaiian pizza (The Sunset Aloha) is fantastic. They use pancetta instead of ham. I'm going there right this second for one. 

Get a bowl of olives for 2 bucks. YUM!

THEY NEED A BETTER BEER SELECTION! Helllllo?
author: Carlo S.

description:
I really want to love this place and give all five stars but it's tough. The pizza is good and the service has gotten better, but damn does it take a long time to get your food.  Been there a half dozen times and it's the same thing every time... Minimum 30 - 40 minutes to get your food - not ideal for a pizza joint, especially when you show up with hungry kids.

I understand the process for this particular style of pizza takes a little longer, and it is good, but its still tough sometimes. If they can figure out a way to speed it up, the place would be perfect
author: John R.

description: Very nice thin crust pizza - we had the "Dimitri," which is sausage, roni, mushrooms, garlic.  Great crust, probably too heavy on the toppings though b/c it made the crust soggy in the middle.  Next time, will go for a simpler pie.  The sweet potato fries are AWESOME - an actual sweet potato (or two) that has been sliced into thick chunks and deep fried, served with two dipping sauces (spicy buffalo and some sweet mayo aioli relish thing) ... piping hot, lightly salted ... eight bucks a little steep, but tasted so good.
author: david l.

description:
Summary: Believe the hype!

Great place! Very comfortable atmosphere and friendly staff.  Prices are fair and service is good.  And the food is excellent (and big portions)!  Good beer selection as well.

Buddy of mine says "ya gotta try the spaghetti and meatballs"...really?!?!, well, he was right...this seemingly ordinary dish (that is not generally one of my faves) was delicious.  

The salads are amazing (and huge - get one and share!). Only problem is deciding which one to have...Iceberg w/radish, walnuts etc is great, but so is the mixed greens (and they had an arugula salad special last time that was heavenly).  

The pizza was good - frankly I was so floored with the other food that the pizza didn't seem all that special, but it was certainly good and admittedly I've only had a total of like two slices so really need to give it a fair shot.

Worth the trip to the Outer Sunset for this one!!

Edit: Did I forget to mention the buffalo wings? Without getting into discussion about various styles of wings, these are just flat-out delicious!
author: Steve E.

description:
I was very happy with the food.  It was highly reminscent of Angelo's Pizza on 57th (@ 6th) in Manhattan -- my FAVORITE pizza place in the entire country.

If you haven't seen this place, its very laid back, very mellow.  Lots of natural light, interesting beers on tap, nice wine selection and great great pizza.  

Also, it seems like kind of a surfer haven.  Its not far from the water and the staff all look like either surfers or skaters to some degree.  This is not a bad thing.  

My only knock is that our order took more than an hour.  An hour?  Really?  

But net-net, we'd go back again.  No question.
author: John R.

description:
I was so happy to see this place open up, giving those at the beach an option other than Brother's on Taraval or the weird place next to the 7-11 or G-D Pasquale's, which always seems to overcharge. 

Anyway, yeah, digging it. The vibe is really nice, neighborhoody, a chill place to have a slice and a beer (not that I drink much beer, but hey, theoretically speaking) on a Friday and unwind. 

The menu's a bit limited at the moment but I heard it will be expanded to incuded sandwiches. The pizza is E. Coast stylee (yeah!) and aight, for sure, and the one salad I had was good. The staff is super friendly and I LOVE the mixed silverware. 

And any place that names a pizza after our beloved Dmitri, well, you gotta holla.
author: Cake M.

description:
WHAT I LOVE
Marinated olives as an appetizer. I LOVE OLIVES & only $2.00
Delicious sweet potato steak fries
Awesome thin crust pizza, Rotten Robby, Spicoli, Timmy's (veg) 
Good selection of beers. 
Huge loyal following.
A couple of blocks from the beach. Could make for a great picnic on a not windy day.
SURFER DRESSED IN 70'S DENIM PATCHWORK BELLBOTTOMS WITH A FAKE FUR WHITE VEST, NO SHIRT, AND A NEWSBOY CAP-PRICELESS

WHAT I DON'T LOVE
So noisy you can't hear yourself think.

I am a sunset native so my loves of the place will always override the noise level here.
author: Maria M.

description: Yum. If I have to eat pizza, this is a nice local place. Its kid friend, and the spinach salad classes the place up a bit. The Dimitri pizza is spicy, and worth the calories and the water you'll have to drink to compensate for all the sodium...
author: Gwenn G.

description:
Since the Pizza Place first moved in, I've been a huge fan. This is by far my favorite spot to get pizza in the city. The food itself is awesome (I always get the Meathead, and highly recommend the wings), the staff is really cool, and in general the place has a great vibe. This is definitely a spot for the surfers, and it's rare that I don't run into a friend or two when i stop by. The owners, cindy in particular, are really friendly and cool. 
It's great to see how the Pizza Place is bringing life to the Outer Sunset. I think they're a great addition to our neighborhood and showcase some of the great community that is out here.
author: Mark L.

description:
Enjoyed the pizza and the atmosphere.  A nice outer sunset vibe to go with your slice and beer.  Extra credit for Chevy on the wall with the pepperoni pizza wheels spinning round and round...

In addition to the pizza, we tried the antipasto plate, and it was delicious.  The herbed bread that comes with it is warm, and the cheese is served in cubes rather than slices.

Check it out!
author: Rusty M.

description:
This place originally use to be a sandwich spot and was one of my favorite sandwich places until the lease was up. Now, it's The Pizza Place. 

  My buffalo wings were not so great, I prefer Domino's buffalo wings instead. The pizza was okay, seemed really oily and greasy to me, but I had a large sized pizza with some friends and the size was HUGE! I still enjoyed it because it was thin and crunchy. The prices were fair. Now as for the service: my first server seemed like she hated her job and was dying to get out of there since we had another server come in after a few minutes. Plus she just threw our plates down when my friends and I did nothing to offend her in any way. The second server was very friendly and kept checking up on us every now and then. Overall, an A-OK place.
author: Pudgy G.

description: One thing that really bugs me about food done wrong is when it is over seasoned with salt. I already had my suspicions about this place from the outside. It looked closed. Actually, it didn't look just closed, it looked shutdown. I arrived late so my table already had an order of what looked like the Meat Head. One bite had my cringing over how salty it was. I managed to finish it with plenty of soda and water to wash out the burning salt taste. Next we ordered the Sunset Aloha, which appeared to be a Hawaiian pizza. Maybe this will be less salty because there's pineapple I thought. Wrong. It was just as salty as the previous meat-filled slice. I realized I wasn't the only one who thought this was too salty. We agreed that it had to be in the tomato sauce. I love pizza, but I really hate pizza done wrong. I will agree that their sizes are pretty large. The service was also pretty good as I didn't have to ask for a drink refill.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
I really like this place and I live across the street, so it's a convenient hang-out. It's fun and unique and a comfortable place to hang out. I always get a kick out of the giant car on the wall with the spinning pizza-shaped wheels. The only thing is the pizza is waaaay too greasy. I always have grease running all over the plate, and it's gross. I usually mop up what I can with a napkin before eating, and it gets drenched with grease- yuck! I would probably eat more if it weren't so oily. I like the thin crust, though.
The servers are friendly and I like the mural on the outside wall- livens up the neighborhood.
author: Amber S.

description:
The pizza place. It is the place to get pizza near the beach. 

It's the flat kind, and you want it in the shop, with a cold beverage. (The take-home is fine, but it does lose something.) It is not fancy, nor should it be.

The people are nice. I like the one with potatoes and pesto, but all the kinds I've had are pretty good.
author: James R.

description:
Was referred here by a client of mine!! Thank you Kate!  And of course after the referral i had to check it out on yelp it passed all my criteria... ordered to go a large Timmy's Pizza (vegan style)... Let me tell you it was DELICIOUS!! I am usually a thick crust pizza kind of girl, which was why i was a little hesitant to try it, but the crust was actually the best part. It was nice and crunchy, good texture and flavor and i loved the toppings on this vegan pizza!!
A large is HUGE!! For $22.00 you cannot go wrong!  Definitely will be ordering again!
Too bad they dont deliver... oh well cant have it all right?!
author: Shelley N.

description:
i've been wanting to hit up this place for a while, and i'm glad i did!

the pizza was delicious, the beer was reasonable, and the appetizers were unexpected.  conversation may be a bit tough in this place during peak hours as the acoustics make this place a bit noisy.

i was def a fan of the pizza.
author: Ameer N.

description:
A year and a half after it's opening I finally noticed (thanks to my coworker) the pizza place 2 blocks from my house. 

Is it the best pizza in San Francisco? It might be if you love thin crust pizza. 

The atmosphere is pretty lively inside and the staff is super friendly and happy. I caught them dancing behind the bar while I waited patiently for my slice of Margherita.

Price is reasonable...around $3.5 per slice. Large pizzas can get pricey...I think they're at least $25. Other things on their menu is salad and buffalo wings. 

My Margherita was not what I expected. It tasted fine but they use chopped basil instead of the fresh leafy kind that i'm use to. Other than that I have no complaints. 

This place looks like it would be a fun hang out place. Thank god there is something in the outer sunset now besides Dominos!
author: Terry D.

description: Pretty good greasy ass pizza.  The crust was tasty.  The skinny cow and I ate half a medium then we both polished it off for lunch.  She was disgusted I ate it cold.  I like it when I see grease turn into an orange block.  This place is too far out in teh avenues to be a regular.  I'll stick to north beach,
author: Fatty A.

description: I used to live in the Outer Sunset, and whenever my roommate and I had out of town guests, we would always order a vegetarian pizza from The Pizza Place on Noriega for us all to enjoy when they arrived. The pizzas are HUGE, like, seriously. The veggies all tasted very fresh, and if we put in a phone order, the pizza was typically ready for pick-up in an acceptable time frame. I only ate-in once, during the Giants' World Series, and it was so fun to see a lot of Outer Sunset neighbors hanging out here, enjoying pizza, beer, and the game. In addition to our usual pizza, we ordered the sweet potato fries, which were SO GOOD. Just order them and see for yourself. The service was a tad slow, but it was also a full house that evening. All in all, though, it's good quality pizza!
author: Tina H.

description: Good pizza joint in the Sunset. Service was a little slow and our waiter was most likely stoned but good pizza joint none the less. A little greasy but that is what napkins are for. Be prepared to wait cause it does take at least 30 minutes for the pizza to come out cause they use a brick oven.
author: Darius A.

description:
Yes! A great pizza place within walking distance! Had the veggie pizza on Friday night - it was definitely the best I've had in San Francisco. Usually we have to make the trip to the East Bay for Zachary's (sp?) if we want great pizza, but no more! 

Very vegetarian/vegan friendly. Their Buffalo Sweet Potato Wedges are amazing. The buffalo sauce is killer. 

Good wine and beer selection too, and just a great laid-back vibe. This place will make the fog months a little easier to take.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Ok one more review to put it all together.

Now, I've eaten here about a dozen times. Simply put I like the pizza. They sell Medium and Large. Medium is enough basically for 3 people and large is ginormous, 8 giant slices. The ingredients are good and the crust is thin. The pizza is on the greasy side, but unless you have an aversion then you'll be fine. The pizza (even on a large)) can be folded up and shoved in your mouth, if you like to eat it that way. otherwise you're gonna need a fork.

The joint is pretty spacious and almost always hoppin. The staff is nice. Nothing super special, but nothing at all to complain about.

All in all, this is my goto spot in south sunset, even though they dont deliver!! You'll definately see me making the trip for takeout when I can afford it. 4.5 stars because 5stars is reserved for little star!
author: Josh S.

description: Great pizza, great service, good beer and good value!
author: LJ S.

description:
Let me admit first that I'm a serious NY pizza snob, so keep that bias in mind while you read this.
